text:
Raj--

Jim Jones just called to tell me he remembered a food distribution system the Air Force used in Bosnia. They dropped cardboard boxes w/out tops filled w MREs from the backs of low-flying C-130s. The air pressure caused the meal packages to inflate so they floated to the ground. They did that every night for months w/out any injuries on the ground, feeding thousands of people. He's asked the Air Force to plan to do that here, and I urged him to push for the decision to be made to try this by Tuesday night. He's also told Gates and Mullen about this and expressed surprise that no one else recalled it being done.

I told Gen. Jones I was going to tell you about it so we could consider and assist in execution if plan went forward. Please find out if anybody at AID knows about this and reach out to the military (probably Gen. Keen) to discuss. And let me know so I can help push.

text:
To set the record straight: our civilian surge efforts have been impressive and have met the commitment made by you and the President in the Afghanistan-Pakistan Strategy in March 2009 as well as his West Point Speech in December of 2009. As we committed, we have more than tripled our civilian numbers in Afghanistan — going from 320 personnel and barely 40 in the field in January, 2009, to 1134 interagency civilians with 407 of those personnel in the field as of May, 2011. In many cases, our civilians are operating in extremely dangerous situations right alongside the • military. Moreover, each year we recruit, train, and deploy a nearly complete replacement team — as the military does, only with a far smaller base of personnel.

I suggest you call David Ignatius sometime next week laying this out as well as the broader issue.

Tom

Greetings from Bangladesh!!!

Bangladesh Foreign Minister Ms Dipu Moni will call on Secretary Clinton on September 16 to discuss the details of the visit of Bangladesh Prime Minister Ms Hasina Wazed to the USA during the UN General Assembly meeting. Please see if the issues of Grameen Bank can be raised in a friendly way.

I received this message after our morning meeting. If you have contrary info, pls let me --know:

I heard through the grapevine that Meianne Verveer briefed on a few DRC-related items today at the 9:15 and I'm not sure she had the latest information, so just wanted to pass to you in case you are interested.

First, I heard that she said that the Central Bank in Goma had been looted and that all the gold had been removed. I double-checked with post and we understand that M23 attempted to rob the bank, but that MONUSCO (which is conducting 84 daily patrols in Goma) intervened and was able to recover everything that M23 started to take out. (They did this without a fight.) At this time, the bank is not missing anything.

Second, I heard that she said that M23 had blocked the roads and no food was getting into Goma. It is true that M23 controls the roads and the airport, but there is food inside the city and humanitarian actors are able to travel into and out of Goma. Humanitarian aid delivery continues despite the airport's closure, as supplies continue to arrive in Goma via truck and from the Goma/Gisenyi, Rwanda and border. Humanitarian staff in Goma have been able to reach over 110,000 people in each of the last two days with water and sanitation materials; and WFP's food distributions have been largely uninterrupted for the more than one million people in North Kivu who are food-insecure. This is not to say that we do not need to keep a close eye on the situation, but, under current conditions, there is not a risk of food running out in Goma.

text:
Please pass to the Secretary

Madame Secretary,

I wanted to follow-up with you on my earlier note about the security situation in Monterrey. We have been working very closely with Pat Kennedy to assess all of our options. Pat has shown tremendous flexibility and has provided excellent counsel.

As we looked further into the Aug 20 shooting incident at the American School, it became clear that there many competing versions about the causes behind the incident. We decided that it is best to leave this matter to local law enforcement officials and to concentrate our review on whether it is possible to provide adequate security for the children of U.S. personnel in Monterrey.

Our discussions with police and other security officials made clear that local police and private patrols do not have the capacity to deter gangs and cartels from areas around the schools attended by the children of U.S. personnel. Local authorities, we found, are not able to respond in a predictable and effective manner to calls for assistance. Given the increasing level of violence that is occurring all over Monterrey, including near where our children go to school, we determined that the only immediate, practical, and reliable way to reduce the security risks for all children is to relocate them to the United States.

We are working with Pat Kennedy on the appropriate mechanism to formalize these arrangements. I have also advised Secretary Espinosa and Nuevo Leon Governor Medina that we are moving in this direction. In parallel with this, I recommitted to our Mexican counterparts that we will continue to do everything possible to support their efforts to improve the security environment in Monterrey and other parts of the country.

Thank you for your support on this matter.

Carlos Pascual

text:
Dear Secretary Clinton,

Deputy First Secretary of Northern Ireland, Martin McGuinness, arrives in DC this week, and I understand you will be meeting with him. As one of your Observers to the International Fund for Ireland, I have concerns about the situation on the ground in Northern Ireland and would welcome an opportunity to discuss this with you.

My principle concern, based on my observations, is the degradation of, and lack of respect for, the rule of law. I fear that, acting out of self interest, Unionists and Nationalist politicians in Northern Ireland are presenting a rosier picture than what is warranted. With the British and Irish governments distracted by by their economic difficulties, renewed American attention and energy is very welcome.

Your meeting with Deputy First Minister McGuinness illustrates America's dedication, not just to the letter of the Good Friday Agreement, but to the spirit of the Agreement as well.

With deep appreciation for all you have done, and are doing, to sustain the peace in Ireland.

Sincerely,

Stella O'Leary

As we close up shop here in the Embassy's control room, here are final observations from our teams:

- Polls closed on time throughout the country, and counting began in an orderly fashion. Poll closing was more problematic in the Port-au-Prince area; some voting centers obeyed the 5pm extended closing but others did not. There were no reports of violence relating to closing of voting centers. OAS, CNO and other groups report the same overall satisfaction with the voting process.

- U.S. and Canada teams reported across-the-board results in favor of Michel Martelly. Obviously, this is just anecdotal, but so far we have Martelly leading 12,160 to Manigat's 3,311. Local press is beginning to report numbers in favor of Martelly in Port-au-Prince. International press is reporting smoother elections than November 28 and uncertainty regarding turnout. Mulct will make an official statement this evening, but it hasn't been released yet.

- OAS speculates turnout was around the same as November 28, perhaps a little higher because more people were able to find their polling places. It's impossible at this point to make any judgment about turnout.

We will have Embassy people at the CTV starting when it opens tomorrow at 6am.

Here are two great pictures to end the day — the first is of a woman voting, and the second is vote counts taking place.

text:
Jake,

Jeremy said you took note of the Islamist protests and asked for an assessment. Here's my quick take.-Andrew

Islamist forces do not command nation-wide support and probably do not represent a direct political threat to the TNC, but their advanced battlefield experience and access to weaponry could pose a significant military challenge.

• The Islamists are not particularly popular outside of certain areas of eastern Libya. Sallabi and his followers are as vilified as Jibril in much of the country. Indeed, many of the political groups that oppose Jibril, such as those centered in Misrata, view the Islamists with equal, if not, more hostility.

• Both Islamist and secular militias have operated with relative restraint so far. With Sirte and Bani Walid still in regime hands and Qadhafi on the loose, there is enough of a rationale to support continued cooperation.

• However, once operations against Qadhafi and the regime are wrapped up, this force for unity is likely to dissipate. It is at this point that militias, including the Islamists, will probably abandon caution and pursue a more aggressive campaign for power, perhaps including violence.

Even though the Islamists may not be able to displace the INC. Jibril and his allies suffer from a serious credibility problem. If the INC fails to make strides in giving other political movements (in Tripoli, Misrata, Zintan, and elsewhere) a real role in governance, it may find itself without a viable national political base.

text:
First of all, Happy Birthday! I hope you are getting some well deserved R and R today because your schedule tires me out just seeing it on television!

And thank you for your kind wishes and offer of help. I may ask your press shop for some small assistance in the next week. But much more importantly, I hope you will share with us your ideas on all issues, including economic and domestic - no one better understands the environment and the levers to change it than you. text:
Dear Secretary Clinton:

During the course of the Fifteenth Anniversary joint Review of the Compact of Free Association between the United States and Palau, I had to convey disappointment at times with positions taken by some Department of State personnel. I am writing today, however, to compliment the letter that Acting Assistant Secretary Rodriguez sent Chairman Bingaman of the U.S. Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources April 5th regarding the Senate bill to implement the Agreement produced by the Review and also to compliment the efforts that Deputy Assistant Secretary Reed has made regarding the Agreement.

The letter and efforts have displayed deep understanding of the relationship between our freely associated states and the mutual benefits flowing from this special association as well as what is needed to approve the Agreement and continue the association.

Let me also take this opportunity to express great appreciation for the instrumental actions that you and members of your staff took to resolve Review issues, for work done by then Deputy Secretary Lew, and for the involvement of Assistant Secretary Campbell. This attention was absolutely critical to obtaining agreement. I took very seriously the advice given through Jeff Farrow last summer that the Review should be concluded so that an agreement could be approved last year and am grateful for the opportunity that we then had to finally negotiate the issues as well as for Secretary Reed being the negotiator.

Although the Agreement ultimately was sent to the U.S. Congress this year, I am confident that continued perceptive efforts, such as those by Secretaries Reed and Rodriguez, will result in a continuation of the free association between our nations.

Sincerely yours,

hnson Toribiong President Republic of Palau

I got a call a few minutes ago from Ned Martel of the Washington Post. He is doing a story on an alleged White House contemplation with replacing Tim Geithner with Hillary Clinton. His angle was that, among other things, they decided not to pursue it because of the prospect of moving a substantial percentage of the Clinton team to Treasury and the relentlessness with which Cheryl Mills pursued the December 2008 agreement between the President-elect Obama and Senator Clinton about her prerogatives in forming her own team. I told her we dealt with a steady diet of rumors about the VP swap, but I never heard this rumor. I also suggested by the time Tim allegedly offered to leave, HRC was arguably the administration's most effective performer (along with Gates). It was highly unlikely the President would want to break up that tandem that was working so well. When he mentioned trouble with the White House over placements, I said there was a joke going around Washington that Clinton campaign supporters were more successful in getting jobs in the Obama administration than Obama campaign staffers. At the end of the process, Cheryl Mills was very effective in building a team that has worked successfully on behalf of the President and Secretary.

Over to you guys. I'll go back to grading final semester papers.

PJ

text:
I am in the office and working with our Embassy in Tegucigalpa. Apparently, the action this morning was a coordinated effort by the Supreme Court, the Honduran Congress, and the armed forces to prevent President Zelaya from holding a non-binding poll on a possible constituent assembly. The Supreme Court determined the poll illegal and ordered the military to collect all balloting materials. In the process of doing this, the military also seized Zelaya and supposedly sent him by aircraft to Costa Rica.

Our Ambassador has his Emergency Action Committee convened at the Embassy. They are reaching out to all their contacts to determine the current state of play. The Embassy will issue a warden message soon to U.S. citizens in Honduras regarding events. I have called our Embassy in Costa Rica and asked it to confirm Zelaya's presence in San Jose. I will be calling the Costa Rican Foreign Minister soon. Tomorrow, Costa Rica takes over as President Pro Temp of the Central American Integration System.

Hector Morales has been in touch with OAS SecGen Insulza. The OAS Permanent Council passed a resolution on Friday offering its good offices to Honduras to resolve the political impasse, and Insulza was going to lead a team to Honduras on Monday. We are checking to determine the state of play of the delegation, but OAS involvement will be key to a successful resolution of this event.

I will also be calling the new SouthCom Commander to ensure a coordinated U.S. approach. We have big military equities in Honduras through Joint Task Force Bravo at Soto Cano airbase.

If our early assessment of today's election in Honduras holds, we will have just been witness to a remarkable thing: Honduran voters have taken back their democracy from two failed leaders -- Zelaya and Micheletti -- who had driven Honduras to isolation and despair.

The turnout (probably a record) and the clear rejection of the Liberal Party shows our approach was the right one, and puts Brazil and others who would not recognize the election in an impossible position. As we think about what to say, I would strongly recommend that we not be shy. We should congratulate the Honduran people, we should connect today's vote to the deep democratic vocation of the Honduran people, and we should call on the community of democratic nations (and especially those of the Americas) to recognize, respect, and respond to this accomplishment of the Honduran people.

Finally, this Administration, which worked so hard to manage and resolve this crisis, should be the one who defines the results and perceptions of today's vote, and not our critics on the Hill (who had no clear pathway to elections) or our adversaries in the region (who never wanted this day to happen).

text:
Dear Bob,

Prime Minister Papandreou stuck to the usual script in his annual speech in Thessaloniki over the weekend, but announced no new measures. Venizelos, however, announced a new property tax levy (to be collected via electricity bills) in a desperate effort to raise more revenue. There is widespread backlash against this latest tax increase. Even those who have supported the government up until now believe that this is the wrong way to go and that the PASOK government is refusing to do what really needs to be done which is to slash public expenditures by eliminating positions or furloughing unneeded employees, and to get serious about collecting taxes from those who still do not pay.

Against this backdrop, we continue to hear more and more rumors of either early elections or some sort of "grand coalition" government. The problem is, of course, that early elections will not likely resolve anything. New Democracy leader Samaras has not changed his critical tone and continues to insist that somehow he would be in a better position to "negotiate" with the Troika. While New Democracy did join forces with the government last month in passing much-needed educational reform, they have not shown any inclination to help the government on much tougher measures to streamline the bureaucracy and trim public expenditures. In their defense, however, the ruling party itself remains intensely divided on this score, which is doubtless why the government keeps going back to the same well when it comes to short-term taxes or revenue "fixes."

What more can I say? Most Greeks are back from their August vacations, strikes are again a daily occurrence, and more labor and social unrest seems likely. The weather, however, is terrific. I will keep you posted. All the best, Dan

text:
Statement of the OAS Secretary General on the Summit of the Americas

The Secretary General of the Organization of American States (OAS), Jose Miguel Insulza, today recalled that in April 2009, "at the conclusion of the Fifth Summit of the Americas, its Chair, the Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago, Patrick Manning, remarked upon the existence of a clear consensus that the reintegration of Cuba in the inter-American relations is an essential step toward the building of a more cohesive and integrated Americas."

Insulza added that "in fulfillment of that consensus, the 39th OAS General Assembly in San Pedro Sula annulled the Resolution through which the Government of Cuba was excluded from participating in the inter-American system." The Resolution of the 39 GA/OAS established that: "the participation of the Republic of Cuba in the OAS will be the result of a process of dialogue initiated at the request of the Government of Cuba, and in accordance with the practices, purposes, and principles of the OAS."

Secretary General Insulza noted that "that request has not been made."

For more information, please visit the OAS Website at www.oas.orq.

Just prior to your speech in Dakar, you will meet (in a receiving line) with Binta Diop and a few women from the women's campaign initiative. They have been recognized as having played a very crucial role in the outcome a peaceful outcome to the election (at a time when chaos could have ruled the day). Just after he was elected; the President went out of his way to thank the women for the role they played (they had established a Situation Room and excellent grassroots operation) in enabling a peaceful transfer of power. Binta is the head of Femmes en Solidarite. She is well known globally, and you may have met her over the years. She is a huge fan of yours. The Senagalese women's efforts are now being recognized as a model that could be replicated for elections in other African countries.

On another note, Binta told me that Zuma has recently reached out to her and is also consulting with Sirleaf, Banda, etc, on ways the AU can better incorporate women into its work and address some of the key challenges in Africa. I think you are tentatively meeting with Zuma.

Melanne S. Verveer Ambassador at Large for Global Women's Issues U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street NW, Room 6805

MS— My heart is breaking this week for the whole extended state department family. What a terrible loss and unbelievable heartbreak. Many of my old friends at the State Department who have moved onto other posts wrote to me to tell me how moved they were by your remarks. I watched it from here on the west coast with great sadness. I am sure that your remarks also meant a great deal to the families of the victims.

"My" Bill is going to see "your" Bill tomorrow afternoon. I was hoping this might happen in our offices in the suburbs so I could say hello, but they're going to meet up instead over at the convention center in downtown seattle. Since Bill never uses staff when he is "off-campus" in Seattle, I will miss seeing the WJC team, but I hope he has a successful trip. It's the best time of year to be out here — picture-perfect weather and breathtaking views of the mountains.

I think of you (and the whole team) often and love keeping up with your travels on the news and the State Department facebook posts!

text:
Dear Madame Secretary:

A major crisis has erupted in Abyei in the past 24 hours. A SPLA (south Sudan army) force attacked an UNMIS convoy carrying north Sudan (SAF) soldiers, wounding several SAF soldiers and an UNMIS member. This is the second unwarranted SPLA attack on SAF members in May, the last attack having killed eleven SAF. The SAF has responded to this latest attack by moving more troops into Abyei and reportedly bombing two villages. We are facing a threat of major war breaking out in Abyei, threatening the entire CPA negotiations.

If it is at all possible, we would like you to make some of these calls today. We are working with you staff to see if your schedule permits and to provide you with the necessary background and talking points. I will keep you informed of developments throughout the day.

Thank you.

Jake, I am forwarding a memo to S regarding Commerce's preliminary decision to terminate a 1996 agreement with Mexico that suspended a US anti-dumping investigation on Mexican tomatoes. If confirmed, the decision would open the door for a new antidumping case against Mexico, which the GOM claims will severely impact a $2 billion industry that employs 350,000 people. There have also been veiled threats of retaliation against US agricultural products.

I received a call from the Mexican Embassy about this yesterday. They are incensed. I would not be surprised if this becomes a major news item in Mexico over the weekend, which is why I thought S might want to know. I do not expect any substantive changes in the memo, which is pretty straightforward but is taking its time winding through the bureaucracy.

Happy to talk over the weekend if you'd like.

Best, Jose

text:
Final Sitrep: On May 14, 2010, the Israeli Consulate at 800 2nd Ave., NY, NY received a white powder letter, which was subsequently placed in a containment hood. No employees were slated for decontamination. The letter with enclosed threatening communication was packaged and submitted to the NYC Dept. Of Health for further biological testing.

Details: At approximately 1400 on 5/14/10, a mailroom employee at the Israeli Consulate noticed a suspicious piece of mail with no return address and 4 stamps. While attempting to contact his supervisor, the mailroom employee noticed the letter was leaking a white powder. He contacted his supervisor who in turn put the letter in a glove box as per their mailroom safety protocol. The supervisor opened the letter in the glove box and discovered the white powder.

text:
Cheryl,

You had mentioned this morning that the Secretary was interested in the possible deployment of the Comfort to Chile. I asked my staff to check with WHA to see if this was something they were working. I'm told that because of the need to resupply the Comfort in Baltimore and consequent travel time, the concern is that it will not provide nearterm medical assistance. USAID/OFDA is supporting the deployment of the Air National Guard's Expeditionary Medical Support (EMEDS) unit, composed of 57-person medical team, six tents, and medical equipment and supplies to treat up to 3,000 patients. According to USAID/OFDA staff at U.S. Southern Command, the EMEDS will likely be located in BioBio Region, northwest of most-affected Concepcion city. The EMEDS is capable of providing laboratory, radiology, pharmacy, and dental services to affected individuals. In addition, the EMEDS has the long-term care capacity for up to 10 medical or surgical patients at a time.

Please let me know, however, if we need to press the Comfort option. Dan

text:
Cheryl - could you pass this note to the Secretary for me? Thank you. Carlos

Madam Secretary,

Patricia Espinosa will likely see you in Montevideo and mention your trip to Mexico on March 23. One of her concerns is to make sure that other cabinet members who belong to the High-Level Group on security issues also participate. On our side the other two key players are Secretaries Napolitano and Gates. Espinosa will try to make sure their counterparts are there. It would be helpful if you could call Napolitano and Gates and encourage them to come. Napolitano's role on Juarez and the border is especially critical.

I am on the way back to Mexico City from El Paso following the de-brief from an intensive week-long planning session that involved all key US and Mexican security agencies. We have a strong plan. Calderon now needs to make important decisions on command and control, force deployments, and prosecutorial capacity. We are still working on the socioeconomic plan. They can turn the violence around, but they will need to be resolute and clear about responsibilities and authorities. It would be helpful if you could tell Espinosa that you are aware of the plan and affirm the importance of establishing a unified command structure for the security operations in Juarez.

Carlos

This message has been sent via BlackBerry

Jeff believes it would be helpful. This is his assessment:

I've been in touch more or less continually with the Tunisian Ambassador here, who suddenly seems as though his own handcuffs have been at least loosened. He in turn is in touch with Morjane. I know they'd welcome a call. Their requests to us have to be handled carefully. They are trying to restore calm, which on the one hand is a good thing -- violent riots and looting aren't inherently good things, especially now that Ben All has left -- but on the other hand could be, if we're too aggressive, part of a campaign to establish "Ben Ali Lite." The "system" has an interest in self preservation (and I suspect Ben All left because the army and party bosses told him they were jettisoning him). We have an interest in opening up political space.

While the transfer of power to the Parliamentary Speaker puts the interim presidency in more of a gray bureaucrat cog in the system than the PM is, there is a real plus: it acknowledges Ben Ali ain't comin' back. (Constitutionally, the PM assumes the interim presidency for a temporary absence or incapacity, while the Speaker gets it for a permanent departure or incapacity.) We're working with Embassy Tunis on ideas. This is a real opportunity

Public diplomacy efforts across Africa are not only helping us to amplify USG messages at this difficult time, but have actually helped roll back demonstrations and have had a tangible real-time positive effect on what's going on. In Khartoum, PAS contacted an IVLP alumnus and shared USG statements with him, leading him to convince the Muslim organization he is part of to call off a planned demonstration and to express support for the Secretary's statement. In Zanzibar, after the Embassy sent them a statement reiterating public comments by the White House and the Secretary and reiterating long-standing USG support for Tanzania, another Muslim group canceled its planned demonstration to show appreciation for the embassy's statement. The Somalia unit (based in Nairobi) received statements of support both from the new Somali government as well as Somali radio outlets, in response to Somali-language translations of S and POTUS statements. Across Africa, posts have been distributing and amplifying both S and POTUS remarks, using the most appropriate tools available : via social media, e-mailed statements, and by hand or by phone. These activities have born real and important results.

text:
Ambassador LeBaron and Diane Parsont spent a successful hour and a half with Paul Matulic,'a long-standing staffer for the Senate Intelligence Committee, and the committee's deputy staff director, Lorenzo Goco.

They discussed the genesis of the CSCC, how it fits into the interagency process, and some ongoing projects. There were no surprises, and no detailed questions about budget, staffing pattern or other quotidian matters. Instead, the conversation focused on strategy and tactics.

Paul, whom I've known for a few years, is a straight-shooter and a strong PD supporter. More than once during the meeting he indicated how glad he is that the CSCC is a reality, and that he remembers well the testimony that Judith gave to his committee that included plans for CVE. He wrote afterward, "Ambassador LeBaron conveyed a very solid sense of mission in a realistic world. Lorenzo and I were impressed."

Lynne
facts: very solid sense of mission in realistic world

text: Dear Cheryl, My long time and good friend, Glenn Prickett, who is now the number two person at The Nature Conservancy respectfully asked me to put in an encouraging word with Secretary Clinton regarding the invitation that she has received from The Nature Conservancy. I always try to be judicious in my outreaches to the Secretary (and to you), but feel this one is a most appropriate one. I'm sure you know of The Nature Conservancy's longstanding, meaningful and important work in making our world a better place from an environmental standpoint and more broadly. I have been proud to be associated with The Nature Conservancy's efforts for over three decades now and was quite active in my participation and support during my tenure as CEO of Arkla Gas. It was a natural partnership given the environmental qualities of natural gas and the Conservancy initiatives. Donna also was quite active in the Arkansas chapter of The Nature Conservancy. One of the unique strengths of the Nature Conservancy is their strong state network organizations. I am sure that The Nature Conservancy dinner marking their 60th anniversary this Fall will be a well organized and special occasion. Of course, I understand better than most the demands of the Secretary's schedule but sincerely feel this one is worth her full consideration. Thank you for your consideration and for handling these types of matters in your usual professional and courteous manner. Personally, Mack

Brian

text:
1. Romney's insistence that the economy is in steep decline as a result of Obama's policies is more than central to his political argument—it is at the heart of his identity in this campaign. Romney's background as a private equity turnaround specialist merges in his sensibility with his deeply held Mormon belief of himself as the chosen son of his faith to be a redeemer of the country. He must be the turnaround man.

2. Romney's thinking is utterly schematic. He debates as though making a Power-Point presentation without the slides. This, too, derives from his very particular business background.

3. Romney's argument, method and even identity are all bound up in his key point—that he is the turnaround man—and can be crushed by refuting it. Obama should assert that the economy is now in turnaround, cite the 7.8 unemployment and other relevant statistics, observe that Romney has admitted he was "completely wrong" on the 47 percent, underscore that Romney is "completely wrong" on the true state of the economy, that he has the data "completely wrong," is operating from false premises, and that his approach would hurt people and hurt the economy. Obama is the turnaround artist; Romney would be the underminer of the turnaround. He's got the turnaround, just as he admitted on the 47 percent, "completely wrong."

text: The CTV opened at 6am, but started processing PVs in the early afternoon. Initial tests were run in the morning to adjust the threshold number of votes used for referring a PV to the legal unit. This adjustment was necessary because the initial threshold, based on first round turn-out, was too strict and quarantined 80% of the PVs. The new number was determined based on how many of the initially quarantined PVs were deemed valid by the legal unit after review. (Note: Observers have not been informed of the thresholds used.) - Each department will have a threshold number that can be adjusted over time as more data becomes available on voter turn-out. This is in contrast to the first round when the threshold number was fixed and used for all departments. The database will automatically refer any PV to the legal control unit based on this threshold number. - We were pleased with the diligence of the lawyers and the smoothness of the process thus far. In addition, OAS observers and CTV staff indicated to us that the CTV was much more organized this round. Their impressions were that key deficiencies in the process had been addressed. - Progress reports will be posted daily on the CEP website and daily briefings will be held with CTV leadership. Best, SK

text: Translating these principles into action, on December 6-8, the Government of Rwanda, together with the Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Program, hosted a technical review of its Agriculture Sector Investment Plan and convened a high-level stakeholders meeting. At the meeting, development partners and the African Union/NEPAD endorsed Rwanda's plan and agreed to mobilize support for scaled-up financing. The African Union/NEPAD and representatives from the World Bank, UN, donor countries, the private sector, civil society organizations, and NGOs attended the meeting. The United States was represented by a whole-of-government team led by Special Assistant to the President Gayle Smith that included representatives from the Departments of State, Treasury, and Agriculture, USAID, and MCC. Our team committed to improve the quality of our aid; to provide robust financial commitments and technical support; and to work to mobilize additional financing of the Investment Plan. In the new year, we will continue to engage all stakeholders, work with the international community, and build on our experience in Rwanda as we move forward with plans to implement our initiative. Please continue to visit our website: www.state.gov/s/globalfoodsecurity to stay informed of planning for the initiative and to provide input. We wish you a happy new year and look forward to continuing to work closely with you. The Global Hunger and Food Security Team

text:
Walter:

Sorry I was not able to be at the meeting last week.

I just read the WSJ piece and I have to say that I find the continued attacks upon DoS with respect to Internet circumvention very troubling. We have said on may occasions that we strongly support BBG's efforts to obtain additional funding for circumvention tools. However, I worry that the seemingly endless attempts to undermine what DoS is doing in this critical area will impede the efforts you and I are making to bring our two organizations closer together. I was particularly troubled by the following quote from the WSJ piece:

"Some of the dysfunction in State Department priorities is structural. VOA and the other broadcasting services were independently run by the U.S. Information Agency from the 1950s until the early 1990s, when for the brief "end of history" moment after the Cold War it seemed these efforts were no longer as important. USIA was disbanded, but the diplomats of the State Department have little interest in upsettinaother countries by defendina broadcasting or circumvention efforts."

As you know, the Secretary has been very forceful in her defense of internet freedom and international broadcasting. She has spoken publically on this issue a number of times and all of us have raised it, and will continue to raise it, in our meetings with government representatives at the highest level. I would greatly appreciate your assistance in working with me on this and in ensuring that our fellow governors and respective staffs are on board as well.

Thanks.

Judith

Judith A. McHale Under Secretary for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs U.S. Department of State Washington, D.C.

text:
Hi Jake,

I will be in Cairo on August 27 and 28 to lead an economic delegation to pursue the commitments made by S and the President for economic assistance to help the Egyptians close their $12 billion budget deficit and foster economic growth throughout Egypt.

I will be joined by Bill Taylor, Caroline Atkinson, Assistant U.S. Trade Representative Dan Mullaney, OPIC Vice President Robert Drumheller, and Treasury Deputy Assistant Secretary Andy Baukol.

I am coordinating closely with Anne Patterson on private and public messaging and other central elements of the visit.

We expect to (1) begin to deliver upon U.S. bilateral assistance to financial relief to Egypt from its current fiscal and balance of payments pressures; (2) support multilateral funding for Egypt, including an IMF agreement; and (3) promote a closer commercial relationship between Egyptian and American businesses to expand two-way trade and investment.

Bill Taylor and AID Assistant Administrator Mara Rudman will stay on after our ministerial meetings to negotiate the conditionality and benchmarksfor the cash transfer before we submit the congressional notification.

text:
(via Chester Crocker!). Last bit may be useful to our thinking of overarching principles as we approach a new ME strategy...

Obama should address the nation as if we are thinking adults who are capable of looking beyond breathless correspondents and combative cable news anchors to the hard challenges of coping with a region in turmoil. As Sen. John McCain observed on TV yesterday, these are momentous, historical events that could transform a region and bring it into the modem age, with potential global significance. The stakes are very high. And we are not in charge of the Arab awakening. Arabs are. Nonetheless, as a global power we can and should play a constructive hand and help shape events.

He should describe the reasons for the U.S. to respond and to act in a differentiated way - in recognition of the Arab world's tremendous diversity. He should explain why we need a differentiated strategy and why a cookie cutter won't work in such a diverse geography.

How to explain this? He should explain what the differences are in the Arab nations affected by this awakening:

-- they differ by the nature of incumbent regimes (transitioning, ugly autocrats, friendly autocrats).

-- they differ by the nature of the societies themselves and especially the opposition forces that are taking to the streets (sectarian, tribal, secular, Islamist, civil society-led, angry unemployed youth, etc.)

-- and they differ by the nature of U.S. interests in various countries, ranging from marginal to decisively important.

Obama should say why a global power must make choices based on interests and priorities, and why we must avoid childish conversations in which we debate whether the U.S. is showing "hypocrisy" or "inconsistency" when it reacts differently in different cases. Consistency is hardly a virtue if we are consistently wrong.

text:
Friends:

Today I read about Ray LaHood's son and his ordeal in Egypt and it reminds me of the anxiety and fear that I felt a year ago while I was there when the Egyptian uprising started. I witnessed demonstrations, clashes with the police, explosions, gunfire, police walking off their jobs, vigilantism, mass arrests and other chaotic events that accompany major revolutions. The Arab Spring was unfolding before my eyes. It was reminiscent of the civil rights demonstrations of my childhood — exhilarating and scary at the same time.

I so appreciate the extraordinary efforts by my friends in government and in the private sector who worked to get me, my sister and all U.S. travelers out of Egypt safely.

Thank you again. I will never forget your assistance and for the work that you do every day to make democracy a reality at home and abroad.

I am praying for Sam LaHood and his colleagues.

Laura

Laura W. Murphy, Director ACLU Washington Legislative Office 915 15th Street, NW Washington, DC 20005 Office telephone: (202) 675-2305

From our team in Cairo at the Opposition meeting, final session:

After about five hours the group agreed on a composition of the "follow up and communications committee." They will propose to their political bodies that it be a 21-person committee with three seats for the SNC; 2 seats for the KNC; and one seat for the other 16 groups.

This odd formulation was a result of the SNC's need to be perceived as the heavy weight and the Kurdish demand that it have more seats than the Turkmen. Despite getting their wish, the Kurds attempted (right before the vote) to add another seat in their umbrella which angered every participant in the room. text:
I spoke to All Tarhouni this morning. he is planning to visit U.S. maybe as early as december 7-8 and will ask us for meetings in DC to thank the Administration for all its support. He said he has been asked by Jalil to act as an advisor to the TNC. In addition, he intends to play a political role by forming some kind of coalition with disparate groups in the country, especially the militias, to form a bloc for the elections. He is going to Bengazi and said he will try to bring together the "thuwar" revolutionaries from the west and east and other groups to discuss how best to move forward and ensure they have a voice. This could be the vehicle he might "guide" into the elections but worries that it could be hijacked by "elites." He is also considering possibility of forming a political party with them but believes this will take too much time and there is not enough time left for that.

regarding prospects for the new Cabinet and what it can do in the coming 7 months, he believes it can be a 'service" government--it can work on the security issue(absorbing "thuwar" into army and security forces), work on economic issues-liquidity and payments to "thuwar" and martyr families, and prepare for the election. It will not be able to undertake major decisions such as approving new oil leases, rebuilding infrastructure, or setting out new foreign policy directions. He reiterated that there must be room given to al-Keeb to implement a strong government without the interference of the TNC and al-jalil. He said he would use his political voice to remind al-jalil and the TNC that they should not meddle any longer in affairs regarding the running of the country.

All,

Below are the results of the 2nd round:

African Group (1 seat available) • Mauritania 72 • Togo 119

Eastern European Group (1 seat available) • Azerbaijan 90 • Slovenia 97

Bottom line: results inconclusive. Since none received the required two-thirds vote of members present, voting and submitting valid ballots (which is varying in each vote), the General Assembly is immediately proceeding to a third round of voting. The third round is again restricted to the above countries.

If the third round is inconclusive, the fourth round (and 5th and 6th) will be an "unrestricted" round, whereby votes may be cast for any eligible Member from the respective regions, including those that were part of the first round but not part of 2nd or 3rd rounds, i.e. Hungary could get some votes.

Voting for third round has occurred, ballots are being collected, and the General Assembly will soon be in recess again to count the votes.

Dan

text:
Steve—

I understand that plans are afoot to have EUR (Gordon) and SRMC (Pandith) lead the session on CVE at the Chiefs of Mission conference. We find this deeply problematic. S/CT has both the Department and interagency acknowledged lead on CVE. We have by far the most CVE activity going on at State, including a wide range of analytic and programmatic work. When it came to briefing the President on the Secretary's plan for Strategic Counterterrorism, a central component of which involves CVE, she asked me to do the presentation. We represent the Department regularly at the Tuesday WHSR meetings with the President, where we update him on, among other things, CVE; I am slated to be the deputy chair of the CSCC, which is perhaps the Department's foremost major CVE initiative this year.

S/CT has also spearheaded the effort to create a Department-wide CVE community of interest and convened the Administration's first interagency summit on the subject. In the context of our RSI meetings with posts in key regions, we have been working to motivate our ambassadors to innovate in this area. We have run three major international conferences in little more than a year on the subject. We are creating the Global Counterterrorism Forum, one of whose key working groups will be on CVE. Moreover, as I've discussed with both Cheryl and Jake, the transformation of S/CT from its current state to a full-fledged bureau, as envisioned in the QDDR, will center on the role we are developing in CVE and capacity building.

I spoke w President Colom today. He said they had lost 44 people and have considerable damage including bridges that have washed away. Fortunately the rains stopped today-- although he is very concerned about the upcoming rainy season.

-- the Embassy provided 3 NAS helos (with a team of 19 emergency workers) for emergency response to the flooding and landslides .

President Colom expressed his gratitude for Embassy support. I took advantage of the call to also tell him that we have reprogrammed $4.38m to Guatemala for reconstruction for which he was also very grateful.

As you may know President Colom has repeatedly asked whether he might be able to get a meeting w the President--

We think that a meeting is impt not only because of Guatemala's key role in the Merida plus initiative and the fragility of Guatemalan institutions-- but also because of the up-coming revelations of the Cutler study-- (the Tuskegee like experiments in Guatemala). It strikes us that we will be in a better position to react to that damaging news (with its negative connotations beyond the bilateral relationship) within the context of a clear and positive engagement w Guatemala.

President Colom said that he will be at UNGA on the 19 or 20th and I intend to see him then-- perhaps if a POTUS meeting does not materialize you might consider whether such a meeting could fit into your schedule.

Best Regards,

Arturo

text:
Hi Cindy!

How are you? I hope all is well.

I have just returned from a series of field trips to the DRC, South Sudan, Rwanda, Kenya and Burundi - busy developing strategies for our new Cash and Voucher approaches.

You will be pleased to hear that in very many of the countries people I met spoke to me about the important need to address the first 1,000 days of life. I was very pleasantly surprised to hear reference to 1,000 days in some of the most peripheral areas and most difficult humanitarian environments. The countries were I visited had such high levels of accurate malnutrition, and I hope that they can really make progress in addressing the issue.

I remembered the summer of 2010 and I thought to myself that I must write to you and let you know that there is definite impact on the ground.

You mentioned the new arrival here. Yes, I am very excited to see the new direction—WFP is a very exciting organisation with so much promise. I hope we will see you in Rome one of these days too!

All the best,

Simon

Simon Clements Programme Officer (Field Support – ODJ & ODN) ODXC - Cash-for-Change Service UN World Food Programme

text:
HRC,

-- The objective is to try shift the fulcrum of our current relations with Bibi from settlements -- where he thinks he has the upper hand -- to ground where there is greater understanding in Israel of the American position and where we can make him uneasy about incurring our displeasure..

-- .Ironically, his intransigence over 67 borders may offer us that possibility -- to turn his position against him.

text:
New intel, based on Tyler Drumheller's sources:

1. The army is staying out of the street fighting. The pro-Mubarak group provoking the fighting is a small group of former security and police, quite violent but not significant politically. The army is not getting involving. 2. The army doesn't want to humiliate Mubarak. They will not force him to do anything further. But a flashpoint looms. Egypt can only go for a few more days before there is a food crisis. The army is central to food distribution. Within days as a result of a food crisis the army will feel there must be a resolution. In the meantime, the army will do not anything else. Mubarak has dug in his heels. The army wanted him out, but will not do more against him. The army remains in touch with Muslim Brotherhood, which is not driving the revolution but waiting. The army is still in control.

New options

1. The old constitution established that the president could be president for life. Mubarak could call for a constitutional committee to be formed immediately involving all elements of Egyptian politics to amend the constitution abolishing that provision. Mubarak, in fact, mentioned this in his speech, but failed to include any mechanism to realize it. Calling into being a committee would build on what he has already said and begin to end his rule in reality. He could announce that Suleiman would be head of the committee and perhaps El Baradei would be vice chairman.

text:
Kofi Annan's Deputy Nasser Qidwa just spoke with A/S Feltman to share that JSE Annan received a new letter from Syrian FM Muallim that said:

1. The regime is willing to cease all military action in all of its territory by 0600 hours local time (1300 EST) on 12 April.

2. The regime reserve the right to respond proportionally (supposedly the first time it has agreed to this) to any attacks

3. Will redeploy its forces to certain encampment areas and bases, particularly in the governates of aDmsscus, Horns, and Hama.

4. Request updates from the JSE on his efforts with the "other parties" (i.e., opposition).

Qidwa admitted that this may all be a trick or ply to prevent a Russian rapprochement with the UNSC, but said the letter was more straightforward and factual than making excuses. He thought it could represent a new political position, rather than just another tactic. A/S Feltman remained skeptical. Qidwa admitted that, assuming this was true, there were still two schools of thought within the JSE office with respect to monitoring: some wanted to have a ceasefire in place ahead of time, others (like Qidwa) believe that monitors could help improve things on the ground even if things were still "messy." The letter apparently made no reference to shabiha or other security elements, which Qidwa admitted was a problem.

We will a more in depth readout on the high side, but wanted S to have this before her G8 meetings.

Rob McCutcheon Syria Desk

Melanne and Robert: I delivered the Secretary's letter to Father (now Bishop) Gudziak at the luncheon banquet yesterday in Lviv, immediately following his three hour (yes three hour) installation as Bishop in a sweltering St. George's cathedral.

As soon as he saw it Father Borys asked if I would read the letter in front of the 500 or so guests, which included his mother, brother and many family members.

Melanne: I extended congratulations to Father Borys from you, Mariella, me and the many other friends he had in the USG. I then said I had received a letter from another admirer, which I proceeded to read without initially identifying the author. When I got to the end and read, "With blessings and warm regards, I am, Hillary Rodham Clinton" the place exploded in applause.

Father Borys asked me to extend to the Secretary his deep appreciation for remembering him on this special day. Many members of Father Borys' family and his friends, came up to me after the banquet, as well as at the airport this morning, to thank me for the letter which they thought was tremendous.

So thanks for your help in getting me the letter. Well done Robert. You can tell the Secretary that it had just the kind of impact we hoped.

Best, John

text:
Dear Cheryl,

Thank you for the call on Thursday and for your understanding about my need to take care of certain responsibilities before I depart as SCSL Prosecutor.

The Taylor testimony is going well from our point of view. He is opening himself to a devastating CX by telling unexpected and unnecessary lies about his activities in Liberia and the region. I have been using my access to senior Liberian, Sierra Leone, and UN officials to obtain new evidence with which to confront him. This is well in hand and I dont see a problem in leaving even if Taylor is still on the stand on September 7. The major reason to stay as Prosecutor until that date (aside from the requirement of a 30-day notice to the UNSG) is the oral argument on the appeal of our last case in Freetown (involving historic gender violence convictions) on September 2, 3, and 4.

However, from my conversations with Clint, I am concerned that there are several issues that are coming to head at this time, and know that I will have to hit the ground very fast on September 8. Because my schedule is light in the coming week and because I have some leave days to use, I have therefore planned a quick trip to DC to be there from Wednesday noon through Saturday noon, August 26-29. I wont yet move into the office, but the staff will help me schedule some informal meetings on several issues. Additionally, this will give me a chance to look for a place to live.

. I hope that we can talk when I am Washington this week.

Best, Stephen

text:
Hello and Happy New Year Jim,

Friends of WFP has decided to provide its annual "Leadership in the Fight Against Hunger" Award to Secretary Clinton this year. The award is presented at a ceremony on Capitol Hill (within one of the House/Senate caucus rooms). Approximately 200 people attend the event including Members of Congress, NGO representatives, business leaders, administration officials and other leaders in the fight against hunger.

As you know, Friends of WFP is a non-profit organization dedicated to addressing global hunger. Its board members include former agriculture secretary Dan Glickman, former Senators George McGovern and Bob Dole, YUM Brands CEO David Novak, former NSC Advisor Sandy Berger and others. I established the organization in 1997.

Before officially announcing Secretary Clinton as this year's award recipient, we hoped to confirm that Secretary Clinton will be available to personally accept the award. We plan to schedule the award ceremony in September on either a Tuesday or Wednesday evening (at approximately 6:30/7pm). We would select the specific date based on Secretary Clinton's schedule.

I think the ceremony would provide another good opportunity to shine a spotlight on the unprecedented commitment of Secretary Clinton and President Obama to addressing global hunger. Thank you for your help in engaging the appropriate officials in the State Department.

All the Best, Rick Leach

Bill Drozdiak met in Berlin last night with Christof Heusgen, Merkel's national security adviser, and learned the following information:

Immediately after the ceremony taking the oath of office, that very day, Hollande will dramatically fly to Berlin to meet with Merkel. Jean-Pierre Ayrautt, the Socialist Party leader in the National Assembly, from the same area of Normandy, where Hollande was raised, will be named the new prime minister, possibly tomorrow, May 11, or when Fillon resigns, if not that day. Ayrault is a former professor of German and will be a key interlocutor with the Germans. Merkel will not renegotiate the fiscal compact, but with Hollande will agree to new programs financed through the European Investment Bank in Luxemburg for infrastructure building throughout Europe, in effect an annex to the original compact aimed at economic growth. Note that the Bundesbank yesterday raised the level of acceptable inflation, another gesture to growth. Merkel and Hollande may also fly together to Washington for the G-8 summit to demonstrate new European unity.

text:
Jake:

On the assumption that S would like a bit of background on the US economy from time to time, I am sending this along. It pretty well summarizes the current state of affairs-- and why the jobs situation is so weak.

The United States had another month of disappointing job growth in April, the Labor Department said Friday. The nation's employers added 115,000 positions on net, after adding 154,000 in March. April's job growth was less than what economists had been predicting. The unemployment rate ticked down to 8.1 percent in April, from 8.2 percent, partly because workers dropped out of the labor force.

Government job losses totaling 15,000 continued to weigh on the economy, tugging down job growth as state and local governments grapple with strained budgets. Private companies added 130,000 jobs, with professional and business services, retail trade, and health care doing the most hiring. Such job growth is not nearly fast enough to recover the losses from the Great Recession and its aftermath. Today the United States economy is producing even more goods and services than it did when the recession officially began in December 2007, but with about five million fewer workers.

Bob

text:
Cheryl,

I am looking forward to attending the Chiefs of Mission Conference and I'm writing to request a short meeting with the Secretary.

Spain has recently elected a new government, and there are some pending issues that concern me, and I believe the Secretary, which I'd like to discuss with her. These include:

• A White House meeting between President Obama and President Rajoy • Palomares cleanup

• USTR 301 watch list • GOS interest in economic statecraft I know the Secretary has met the new Foreign Minister, Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo, and I'd like the opportunity to share my own impressions of the new government. I've been invited to a working lunch later this week with Spain's Vice-President and Ministers of Defense, Interior and Foreign Affairs, to discuss the whole range of bilateral issues between us. My meeting with the Secretary, following that meeting, will be especially timely. I would also like to brief the Secretary on a major conference the Embassy will host in Madrid at the end of March on volunteerism and service. Assistant Secretary Stock and Special Representative Balderston have both agreed to attend along with a number of service leaders from the U.S. Because of the Secretary's passion for this subject and the emphasis she has give to it, I thought she'd be interested in learning of our plans. I know the Secretary's time is precious, and I can address all of these matters in a short meeting. Obviously, I'm available any time throughout the week of the conference if this meeting can be scheduled. Finally, I had a very productive audience with the King recently, and he asked me specifically to extend his warm regards to the Secretary. Please let her know. Many thanks, Cheryl. Alan

Alan D. Solomont

text:
The hardliners in the regime fought a largely successful counterattack against the deal today, and M appears to be leaning toward their view that if he steps aside he will endanger the elections.

It goes beyond that. For the hardliners this is almost a religious struggle against a Zelaya they view as dangerous, duplicitous and vengeful. As one of the hardliners told me two weeks ago: "We are prepared to die for this."

The modest silver lining is that the military has weighed in on the side of the moderates -- the latter include all three of the de facto negotiators who reached the October 30 Accord.

Hugo believes strongly that I should fly down Tuesday morning for one last, blunt effort. Arturo, Dan Restrepo and I agree. Last time my message, while firm, appealed to M's better angels -- the chance to leave office as a statesman and deal a strategic defeat to Chavez. I will sharpen it tomorrow. The hardliners fail to see how they are playing into the hands of the worst actors in the hemisphere -- ALBA crowing will be part of the de facto legacy. I will also make clear that if the de factos continue down this path we will be forced to underscore our position on the coup in concrete ways

I will make clear that they are undermining any chance we have to increase international support for the elections. As for our stance on elections, Arturo and Hugo will present options to S in coming days.

I depart at 6:00 am and will update you Tuesday evening from Tegucigalpa. ck

Madam Secretary,

I just wanted to drop you a quick note of thanks for everything you've done for me personally and throughout my career. As you can imagine, and with your tenure at State coming to a close, like many I've been doing a lot of reflecting. What I know is that none of what I'm doing now would have been possible had you not taken a chance on a young(ish) lawyer who was still very much learning how Congress works (or sometimes doesn't work).

The time I spent with you and your team in the Senate and at State were incredibly formative. Every day I learned something new. It was like going to school everyday. And the community you created, the brilliant people you attracted to your team -- I count many of them among my closest friends.

So with deep gratitude, I want to be sure to say thank you.

I am in India but wanted to quickly weigh in on the prospects of a Japan stop next week after Europe. I well recognize how brutal the travel schedule has been and have been reluctant to add to that given pressing current circumstances in Libya and elsewhere.

We can do this in one day and have an historic impact, quite seriously given the stakes and gravity of the situation. Happy to develop a schedule to support this effort if warranted. Best Kurt

Dear Team,

Thank you for your comments about what you would like said at the meeting with Secretary Clinton and Senator Graham. I will try to summarize them for you: first you want to express your appreciation for both her having such a meeting and also for defending religious freedom throughout the world. You also want to express the depth of commitment the faith community has to serving the neediest people in the world and give several examples of what you have done. Maybe most importantly you want to share that in order to work hand-in-hand with the government there needs to be mutual respect and an appreciation for differing religious beliefs, and that these beliefs should also be respected. They should not become barriers to working together and we must make every effort to avoid such conflict. Lastly, you expressed an interest in explaining how you want to impress on legislators the need for robust foreign policy budgets and that you plan to work actively to protect both programs and funding for them. I hope that was a good summary.

We should all meet in the lobby of the State Department at 10:00 sharp Thursday morning. At the end of the lunch tomorrow we should also try to meet for a few minutes to go over how we might want to structure the meeting. Thank you for your help in making this a meaningful moment in the challenges we have ahead regarding foreign assistance.

Best, Shepherd

Madam Secretary,

The outpouring of condolences from the international community and the Afghans for Richard's passing has been extraordinary. We have had a steady flow of visitors from the NATO and diplomatic community and, most importantly, Afghans of every walk of life for several days who have come to sign the condolence book.

Today, during my weekly meeting with President Karzai, I took along the condolence book to be signed at the Palace. President Karzai signed and wrote a nice tribute to Richard and graciously allowed us to bring an Embassy photographer to memorialize the occasion. A photograph is attached. We will separately arrange for a copy to be signed by President Karzai for Kati.

Separately, I would ask that you thank Mike Mullen for permitting the USO show with which he is traveling to stage an unprecedented performance at the U.S. Embassy today. Allowing Embassy Kabul to be the site of a USO show in Afghanistan was very gracious of Mike as normally USO shows are only held at military bases. We had an extraordinary turnout of our civilian and military team from all over Kabul gathered today to see Robin Williams and other entertainers. Mike remains a real champion of our civil-military cooperation and teamwork.

text:
Update from Laura

Dear Secretary Clinton,

I am both saddened and excited to inform you that I have accepted a clerkship with a new federal district court judge in the Southern District of California. I am thrilled to jump into the legal aspect of my career, but also sad to leave what has become a family over the last six years.

I dubbed the name, "Hillaryland 2.0" for the group of young women like me who have learned from you and the original Hillaryland - Capricia, Cheryl, Melanne, Huma and even new ones, like Maria Otero. The collective guidance and mentorship from you and these phenomenal women has helped me grow both personally and professionally in an unparalleled way. I assure you that it's a unique experience, distinguished from any other environment that exists in Washington for young women. Under your leadership, I feel that I have also become part of the State Department family, with all the ups and downs that a family inevitably experiences.

I look forward to meeting with you before I leave for San Diego at the end of the month. I know you are incredibly busy, so I appreciate the opportunity to thank you in person for the opportunities you have given me. I never thought a small border-town girl like me would have the chance to travel the world representing the United States, and share with countries all the values that we hold so dear.

There are questions about what impact this move will have on the global financial markets.

Nirav

text:
Cheryl,

I had a good conversation with Amb Jeffrey and he wants me to start immediately. I told him that I was ready to take on this enormous challenge but first needed to talk with you on timing, the reporting chain and staff, plus transition on FtF front (most important to me). On staffing, he wants S to persuade SecDef to appoint a 3-Star counterpoint for the coordinator to work with on OSD side. He is looking at the model that was used to set up the first Iraq office in Washington under Ambassador Ricciardone, Bob Godec, Jeannine Jackson etc. back in 2002/03. I was working on Afghanistan then and had some interaction with the setup team. He could not recall if the team was part of NEA or part of P back then.

He envisions that the "coordinator" will have three jobs related to the transition: be the communication link between all the inter-agency players in DC and in Iraq, especially keeping the Embassy looped in; push the bureaucracy to carry out commitments, especially the military; encourage creativity and flexibility on all fronts dealing with this transition. There are five pieces: OSCI, police/justice training, USG presence, intel sharing/force protection and highend services (medical, medivac, Logcap etc.)

He mentioned that there will be a large transition conference next Friday. Amb Jeffrey, General Austin, Deputy Secretary Nides and Pat Kennedy will all be attending. He recommended that I attend as well.

I am available to discuss this all with you in person or over the phone today, this weekend or next week. I am headed to USAID this afternoon for Liberia's strategic review but can be reached on my blackberry

Thanks, Pat

text:
From John Beyerle ... Perhaps the Russians won't send troops:

I just called Karasin. He agreed that the situation had gotten worse in Osh and Jalalabad today but said the Russian position is still that sending in foreign troops, whether Russian or CSTO, will be counterproductive and lead to more violence and bloodshed.

The IL-76s that flew in to Kant today were the EMERCOM/M4C planes he told me about yesterday; they have humanitarian cargo, primarily doctors and medical equipment. I cited the news reports that a battalion of paratroopers had gone in -- he said there may be some troops on board to guard the plane or beef up security at Kant, but he was firm that at this point Russia has no plans to introduce its own forces in the south. The main objective was to stop the violence through peaceful means; Russia had provided the Kyrgyz forces with additional "technical means" for accomplishing that. He said they hoped this would help Kyrgyz forces get control of the situation, which was their main goal.

I asked about CSTO planning, and possible UN or OSCE PKFs. He said there is no formal CSTO meeting planned, although people are consulting via phone. He repeated their hesitation to see any CSTO deployments. They have not yet considered UN or OSCE PKFs, but if the situation continues to deteriorate, he wouldn't exclude the possibility.

Rushailo is currently in Moscow, but may be sent to Bishkek tomorrow or Tuesday. He agreed to call me if there is any major change in the situation on the ground, or regarding force deployments. Tomorrow is a Russian holiday but he'll have his cell phone on.

Dear Cheryl,

It has been a while since I've contacted you directly. Happy New Year to you and your family. I've been pleased to communicate directly with Ambassador Thomas Adams. His approach and willingness to work with unusual suspects in the Haitian diaspora is refreshing.

Please extend my deep appreciation to Secretary Clinton for filling the vacuum in leadership that exists in resolving the haiti election debacle. Her leadership is moving Haiti from the self imposed paralysis imposed by the first round of elections.

Her clear public message endorsing the findings of the OAS Report gave Haitians/ Haitian Americans here and abroad confidence that a rational resolution was at hand.

The Secretary's personal visit to Haiti, this week in the midst of the crises now unfolding across the globe told many of us that Haiti remains important to her and this Administration.

The Secretary's leadership and personal attention to Haiti sent a message a dozen policy statements could not have conveyed. Building a new Haiti requires all our intellect and labor.

Along the way we will have many points of disagreement. However, decisive, positive leadership and direction in Haiti is welcome. Thank you and your team for making it happen.

Warm Regards,

Marie St. Fleur Chief, Advocacy &Strategic Investment, City of Boston

text:
I have been singing exactly the same tune as below in every speech I give, but your speech tonight was particularly eloquent.

In the 21st century, the material conditions of people's lives have greater impact on national stability and security than ever before. The balance of power is no longer measured by counting tanks and missiles alone. Now strategists must factor in the growing influence of citizens themselves -- connected, organized and frustrated.

There was a time when those of us who championed civil society, worked with marginalized minorities and women, and focused on young people and technology, were told our concerns were noble but not urgent. That is another false narrative that has been washed away. These issues — among others — are also at the heart of smart power — and they must be at the center of any discussion attempting to answer the region's most pressing questions.

Best, AM

I will send you the latest draft of the speech and some topline points and QA in a little while.

The key point to make to these guys tomorrow is the following:

• Around the world, we see countries gaining power and influence not because of the strength of their militaries, but because of the growth of their economies. Meanwhile, closer to home, the American people are hungry for jobs and recovery. We recognize that America's leadership and our economic strength are a package deal—and we are taking steps to shore up both.

• That is why we are putting "economic statecraft" at the heart of our foreign policy agenda. Economic statecraft has two parts: first, how we harness the tools and forces of global economics to strengthen our diplomacy; and second, how we are putting our diplomacy to work to strengthen our economy.

Ultimately, diplomacy and economics are a reinforcing cycle — our diplomacy can help spur economic growth at home (while of course recognizing that the work we have to do domestically, in infrastructure, entitlement reform, etc. is by far the most important thing), which in turn strengthens our economy, which in turn strengthens our diplomatic hand overseas in a world in which economic influence is a primary point of leverage and leadership, and so on.

text:
Dear Secretary Clinton,

Happy Memorial Day! So many veterans must be thrilled to celebrate the holiday knowing that OBL is no longer hatching plots.

I thought the speech was impressive. The beginning — where he thanked you for your tireless efforts -- was a high point, and he deserves credit for identifying the United States as being on the right side of history in a region where so many autocrats are on the wrong side of it. The section with the line about the obsolescence of "strategies of repression and strategies of diversion" was powerful.

Beyond what could be addressed on that occasion, I can't help being wary of the fact that the region remains a place where states are interpenetrated and outside powers have consistently intervened. Turkey is in a very interesting position vis-a-vis Syria, even as Iran and Saudi Arabia compete for influence there; I would not be surprised ifChina were working behind the scenes both to shore up Qaddafi and to cultivate good ties with a range of possible successors; etc. Given these dynamics, in a future address, it might be appropriate to go into further detail in laying out our principles for resolving regional rivalries and disputes -- like you did in the South China Sea context. I also can't help thinking about how the Middle East might look if Iraq realizes its potential as a major energy producer.

Thank you again! All best, Jackie

ps It was my tenth college reunion over the weekend, and Jen and Johann and Aksel were staying with us, so Jen told the story of how Johann confronted you with the world's primary challenge, the bane of Norway.
